posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14359265
The Shroud of Turin was created in the 14th century.

The fact that it was a fake was know since its first appearance.

When the Shroud of Turin was first displayed, the ostensions of the object to the faithful was forbidden twice by the bishops of Troyes, who claim to have discovered the forger responsible for the deception.

In fact, the Bishop Pierre D'Arcis had access to a confession by the artist who had crafted it.

Then, in 1390, Pope Clement VII published a bubble authorizing the display of the shroud. But it was forbidden to present the object as a relic. The display was allowed as long as the object was displayed as a "representation of the shroud of Christ".

Every scientific study run on the Shroud of Turin showed that it was not a relic.

So it is a fake created during the 14th century (around 1350).

>>14361678
No examples of complex herringbone weave are known from the time of Jesus when, in any case, burial cloths tended to be of plain weave. In addition, Jewish
burial practice utilized — and the Gospel of John

specifically describes for Jesus — multiple burial wrappings wrapped tightly around the body with a separate cloth over the face:

“Then cometh Simon Peter following him, and went into the sepulchre, and seeth the linen clothes lie, And the napkin, that was about his head, not lying with the linen clothes, but wrapped together in a place by itself…”

—John 20:1
:6, King James Version

This is particularly curious because the Christian relic
industry has been so proficient at producing multiple Holy Foreskins
and multiple complete sets of Jesus' baby teeth. It must be a "miracle

" that there is only one shroud!

Additionally, none of the gospels make any mention of any miraculous burial cloth after Jesus's resurrection. Curious that the most holy relic in all of Christendom doesn't even get so much as a word in its holy texts, isn't it?

There are also claims of "bloodstains" on the cloth, but Hebrew
law dictated cleansing of the corpse before wrapping and bodies don't bleed after death. Chemist

Walter McCrone identified the substance as a "combination of red ochre and vermilion tempera paint." However only fibrils lifted from the shroud on sticky tape were tested for blood (This was done in order to avoid damaging the cloth). It should be pointed out though that the color observed was still an unfaded red, which would not be expected of real blood, which browns with age.

Also of note is the lack of wrap-around distortion. For a shroud that was supposedly wrapped around the body of Christ, the lack of wrap-around distortion across the torso, thighs and legs is striking. If the cloth were genuine, the face and body should be hardly recognizable as such, and should look something more like this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gold was the densest substance they were aware of.

Silver is also dense. Though not as dense as lead, silver plated lead will bend easily, hence the practice of biting a coin (and receiving lead poisoning in the process). Coins were made thin so that it was difficult to manufacture fake coins with a lead core, coated in iron and plated in silver, more expensive in terms of labor than the materials themselves since they would be hand crafted.

Coins could further be designed to make shaving and other practices more difficult.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because currency is for buying things with utility.

More specifically, currency is a unit that has a similar value to everybody regardless of what is actually useful to them. It's actually much better for that unit to be not very useful to most people, because if people all wanted it for their own use, then it wouldn't circulate and would be an effective medium of exchange. And that's even assuming you could identify a medium that had an equal utility, or value, to everybody. Are you going to trade goat hides to a herdsman? Are you going to sell water to a guy who lives on the river? The magic of currency is that people can exchange goods and services without some coincidence of their needs and means lining up.

Gothic architecture has long fallen out of style due to its prohibitive costs, long construction times, safety concerns about their weight, and reliance on materials such as certain types of stone and glass that are difficult and expensive to source, especially compared to concrete. Not to mention that all that the style greatly restricts the number of uses the building in question has. For instance, you can't really safely put a helipad on a building built in the Gothic style.

In addition, the structural limitations that necessitated the development of the Gothic style have long since been rendered redundant by the advent of concrete and steel beams (unmelted by jet fuel).

>>14361548
There is a written tradition, going back to the early sixth century, that says the first Anglo-Saxons in Britain were mercenaries who mutinied against their British employers and began seizing the island by force. The archaeology seems to say something quite different. The earliest Saxon cemeteries, dating to the mid fifth century and found in the Thames Valley and Essex, seem to be of ordinary farmers. These are poor people, buried without weapons. Their settlements are undefended, and they seem to have existed side-by-side with equally undefended settlements of ordinary Romano-British farmers. There is also considerable evidence for contact between the two peoples: hundreds of British place names survived, the genetics seems to show substantial intermarriage, many old community boundaries were maintained. The culture we call Anglo-Saxon seems to have emerged gradually from the mixing of British and barbarian elements, and not until nearly a century later do we have much evidence for Anglo-Saxon warriors, especially warrior aristocrats

>>14361597
Here have a "micro essay" I wrote on their rulers ought to act. 1/?

Irish literature, especially during the Ulster cycle, often serves as a type of kingship literature. That is, Irish literature seeks to inform the reader about what it means to be kingly, and the lengths a ruler must go through to maintain his standing as a king. “The Destruction of Da Derga's Hostel” and “On the Race of Conaire Mór” both fit this mold, in that they describe the origins of King Conaire Mór, his rise to power, and how to behave as a sovereign ruler. When examined together, it becomes clear that these two different stories work in tandem by telling the audience how a king should behave by describing noble lineage, performing on the battle field and the feast, and maintaining honor by observing taboos and gift giving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361612
2/?

There are many ways in which the tales “Destruction” and “Race” show the reader how a king should be honorable. One example from “Destruction” describes the background and noble lineage of Conaire. The story goes into detail, describing how Conaire’s mother is the daughter of a high king of Ireland and an Irish mythological being. His father was a king in a long line of kings, which passed down to Conaire. Having such a noble and mythological background would give any king added legitimacy, honor, and gravitas. “Race” mirrors this sentiment, by mentioning the kingly lineage and mystical background of Conaire's family in the beginning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361613
3/?

Another way that these two tales show the reader how to be kingly is to have a mighty army. In “Race”, the question of succession is up for debate when Conaire’s father dies. Conaire’s mother sought out a large army full of great men to assist Conaire in asserting his claim to the kingship. The army was so great that the defending claimants to the throne simply fled, leaving all their possessions and their claims to the kingdom behind. Thus, having driven his enemies before him, Conaire has successfully upped his honor by wielding a large army to take something by force of arms. However, in “Destruction”, Conaire does not come to power by force of arms. Instead, he relies on prophecy that says he will be king and stands up for his right at the feast by invoking his noble lineage. On the surface, these two stories of ascension appear add odds with one another. Upon closer inspection, the early and medieval Irish believed how one conducted themselves in battle, and at the self-positioning at a feast was one of the most important parts of being kingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361618
4/?

Being fierce on the battlefield and in the feasting hall wasn’t the only way to show kingly nature. A king must also be mindful of his taboos, and to skillfully negotiate them. In the beginning of “Destruction”, Conaire receives a list of taboos he must not break for dishonor would befall him. One such taboo placed on Conaire is he is to not allow three reds go before him into red’s house. For the Irish, violation of taboos could and did lead to great men dying a humiliating, and undignified death. In total, Conaire has nine taboos, and throughout the story he breaks them, which ultimately leads to his head being cut off. This is reminiscent of Cú Chulainn, who has no choice but to break one of his taboos and is then doomed to die.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14361622
5/5

Conaire didn’t only have an obligation to himself by avoiding taboos, he also had to maintain power by being generous. In “Destruction” and “Race”, Conaire gives many gifts to include land, cloth, weapons, cattle, and swine. He attempts to bribe the three reds that would violate his taboo. The three reds do not accept, which insults his generosity. Irish kings stake their reputation and honor price partially based on remaining in the dominant position by giving gifts. In denying Conaire, the reds have effectively reduced his gravitas, and worth as a ruler.

These two stories allow us to get a glimpse of what the Irish thought it meant to be kingly in nature. While “Destruction” and “Race” are of two different literary styles, they each work towards informing the reader how Irish kings should behave. From having a glorious origin, being strong on and off the battlefield, maintaining honor through observing taboos, and being generous; Irish king’s honor and rule appeared constantly under threat. Stories such as these would help inspire rulers to behave in a kinglier manner.

>>14361655
How honor determined?
>status (all have it, but matter most for nobles)
>gender (mostly male)
>degree of independence (e.g. children, servants, etc.)

The Celts were aggressively competitive. People were constantly challenged in public, where your honor was continually assessed and revised since every single occasion is a venue for loss or gain. Performance on the battlefield to raise your honor is a given, but so is at the feast. Holding a feast by itself is an exercise of power, but that's not all to it. The feast is a very public occasion where you get to boast about your deeds, show off how close you sit to a honorable person, give gifts (which would subordinate yourself to someone) and get gifts (someone subordinating you) in front of everyone. Then there's the curadmír or "champions portion" where only the warrior acknowledged by all to be the strongest would get (and would often cause fights).

>>14361693
Warrior culture also included a key concept known as Geis, or taboos. These can be weird things that make no sense, but the warrior CANNOT break or they'll lose honor AND in the heroes cases, they'll be able to be killed. These taboos could be self-imposed, divine instructions, handed down by fathers and relatives and to break one means a loss of honor.

For example, Cú Chulainn was a hero who had two taboos: first was that Cú Chulainn must take and eat any food offered to him by a woman; the second was that he could not eat dog meat in any form. Can you see where this is going??? He is ultimately offered dog meat by a woman, and to deny either of them would lead to his doom, which it did.

As for the non-mythical, a taboo could be not shirk your duty on the battlefield. For a king it could be to have the right to the first night with any marriageable woman and the right to sleep with the wife of anyone who hosted him (this is attested though).

Daily reminder that Reformers didn’t just ‘make up’ their ideas of Scripture.

> The medieval period in general was characterized by its general conviction that Scripture was the sole material base of Christian theology, thus forcing us to reconsider what, if anything, was distinctive concerning the Reformation principle of sola scriptura

> Indeed, it is evident from even the most superficial reading of late medieval sources that Scripture, and Scripture alone, was regarded as the materially sufficient source and norm of Christian theology

> Neither the slogan sola scriptura, nor the polemical distance this slogan proposes with reference to unwritten traditions or other putative sources of doctrine, is therefore to be regarded as an innovation introduced by the Reformation, nor as an adequate distinguishing criterion of the movement in relation to late medieval catholicism. At this point, as at so many others, the Reformation must be regarded as a continuation of existing dialogs and debates within the ample girth of late medieval theology.

> The anti-Gnostic polemic of the early church led to the develop- ment of a regula fidei, by which Scripture as received by the church was regarded as embodying the Christian kerygma in a materially sufficient manner.92 Although the idea is particularly associated with Irenaeus of Lyons,93 it rapidly became a central theme of the early church’s defense of orthodoxy against threats from within and without the Christian community. All truths that were in any sense necessary to salvation were those given publicly and directly in Scripture, or that could be directly inferred from that same Scripture. Christian theology was thus essentially the exegesis of Scripture within the context of the church.94 This view, although having its origins in the patristic era, was widely accepted in the Middle Ages.

>>14354476
The problem people make in judging God's goodness is that they say "pain = bad" and that's as far as their depth goes into the subject. So if anyone ever got an ouchie before, then God is evil.

But pain is a natural human bodily reaction, and a cautionary sign that you are in trouble and should seek some kind of help. That's why fire burns, because you got too close to it--if we couldn't feel pain, like some kind of leper, then we would go to sleep on a bed of coals and wake up dead after being immolated in fire that we could not sense.

In the same way Christians spurn lust, and wrath, and envy, they should want to spurn pain--not the pain itself, but their reaction to it. Christians cannot control if they feel lustful towards someone, or if they feel angry, or envious... but they can control their actions and reactions to those feelings. That's free will--what separates man from the soulless beasts that act only on instinct.

Even Jesus had his moment on the cross where he asked God why he had forsaken him, but he didn't let the pain undo him and cause him to damn God or cause him to lose his belief. He endured his pain, and he even comforted the thief who asked for forgiveness of his sins. And Jesus' last words before his death were to God, commending his spirit to Him and to Heaven. He survived the pain, his soul persisted.

The greatest mistake people make about this subject is to say that all those with disabilities or defects (or other poor life situations) are "suffering". And more often than not if you ask these people if they're happy... if they enjoy their life... if they find comfort in things around them, they'll tell you they do. It is only those who truly hate their own lives (often without reason) that believe those lesser than them must despise being alive. And I pity those people. And I pray for them.

>Presumably master is lonely, or at the very least lacks something he desires (the company of a cat)
Maybe if you've never had a pet before, or if you were an extremely lonely person, you would think that pets are there only for your amusement... but I disagree. Pets live a very short life in comparison with humans. We are their caretakers, and the way in which we treat them is a reflection of who we are. I have sometimes become sad when my pets have died, but I stopped being sad and I realized that I gave them pretty good lives--I was more important to them than I could have possibly known, as if I were their God--for they were alive for 100% of the time I was, but I will continue after them, and I will need to find other things besides pets to amuse myself with. In some cases I freely chose to let two of my pets mate, so that I might raise their babies, not to keep me occupied or to stifle loneliness but as a simple unrequited act of love and goodness... for if God had not made humanity, how could he know if he were truly all good or not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14358774
>The Challenge, Andrew Lambert.
About the war of 1812, specifically the naval war and economic war.
>The British Way of War, Andrew Lambert. Ostensibly a biography of Sir Julian Corbett, but deals a lot with the pre-WW1 debates about national strategy in Great Britain.
>Thunder on the Danube (3 vols), John H. Gill
About the war of the war of the 5th coalition. One of the best Napoleonic campaign histories I've read.
>England in the Seven Years War: A Study in Combined Strategy (2 vols), Sir Julian S. Corbett
Title says it all, its main focus is in examining the war from a lessons learned perspective rather than a purely historical one.
>Some Principles of Maritime Strategy, Sir Julian S. Corbett
This is really a doctrinal primer from 1907, but it's very eye opening if you have any interest in historical seapower. Makes it far easier to understand the why's of many decisions at sea.
>The Roman War of Antiochus the Great, John D. Grainger
A detailed study of the conflict between Rome and the Seleucids
>Antigonus the One Eyed and the Creation of the Hellenistic State, Richard Billows
One half is a biography of Antigonus and the other half is an examination of how the Hellenistic states developed post-Alexander
>The End of the Bronze Age, Robert Drews
This is a really interesting book regarding the Bronze Age collapse, Drews argues that their was no great migration and that the sea peoples etc, were just the normal dwellers around the fringes of society who'd learnt how to destroy chariot armies and just wanted to kill, burn and maim.

Indigenous just means people who retained hunter gatherer lifestyles and were isolated

>>14360839
It wasn't. There was a constant string of mass murders and war crimes committed by American troops throughout the entire decade of American involvement in the war.
Every major American unit in Vietnam, down to the brigade, had "incidents" wherein Vietnamese civilians were abused, murdered, and raped. The only thing exceptional about My Lai was its scope, killing hundreds at once was a step too far that couldn't be hidden. But the brutalization and killings of civilians was routine.
Even the most cursory examination of the evidence shows this, and it isn't even hidden or disputed. The US military's own analysis showed that during Operation Speedy Express, for example, 5000-7000 of the 10000 Vietnamese killed were civilians. The most outrageous stories there coming from the helicopter and light plane crews that admitted to military investigators that they constantly just murdered anyone they saw for any reason they could think of.
The ubiquitous search and destroy missions were much more up close and personal. Many times these were just covers for the wholesale destruction of a village that happened to be close to a place where a Viet Cong ambush had taken place, or where a GI had gotten injured or killed by a trap or mine. Troops bombed the village, rolled in, burned the houses, killed the livestock, raped the women, and then killed them along with anyone else they could get their hands on. I suggest you read Jamie Henry's account of one such attack. The highlight is really something, and it was attested to by multiple witnesses to military investigators. Or you could read about Roy Bumgarner, who was known as a murderer among troops and was convicted of manslaughter after gunning down four civilians and blowing their heads up with a grenade to teach some new recruits how to conduct themselves.
I can't do the extent of the violence justice, there is too much and I get too angry. I highly advise you look into this, what happened in Vietnam was pure evil.

Tradcath Douay-Rheims-Onlyists make less sense because they can be self-contradicting in their onlyism. The more extreme ones who reject the Challoner revision in favor of the original 1582 Rheims, but then praise the Clementine Vulgate, contradict because the 1582 Rheims was based on the older Leuven Vulgate, not the Clementine. So, they can't be both in favor of the original of 1582 and the Clementine Vulgate because the Clementine Vulgate wasn't published until 8-10 years after the Rheims translation was published. That won't stop them from doing so, though. And besides, most of the Clementine additions to the Leuven were removed in the Nova Vulgata, and ironically originated from the Textus Receptus in several places.

Douay-Rheims-Onlyism also makes no sense because the original Douay-Rheims translators never once claimed their translation was the be-all, end-all. In fact, reading the preface shows they were rather self-loathing about it.

The Phoenician king Hiram of Tyre sent Lebanese cedar, carpenters and masons to Jerusalem to build a palace for King David (2 Samuel 5:11). >>14357757
A lot of Wikipedia is dogshit but this is actually a good definition.

>Postmodernism is an intellectual stance or mode of discourse which challenges worldviews associated with Enlightenment rationality dating back to the 17th century. Postmodernism is associated with relativism and a focus on ideology in the maintenance of economic and political power. Postmodernists are "skeptical of explanations which claim to be valid for all groups, cultures, traditions, or races, and instead focuses on the relative truths of each person". It considers "reality" to be a mental construct. Postmodernism rejects the possibility of unmediated reality or objectively-rational knowledge, asserting that all interpretations are contingent on the perspective from which they are made; claims to objective fact are dismissed as naive realism.

Postmodern thinkers frequently describe knowledge claims and value systems as contingent or socially-conditioned, describing them as products of political, historical, or cultural discourses and hierarchies. Accordingly, postmodern thought is broadly characterized by tendencies to self-referentiality, epistemological and moral relativism, pluralism, and irreverence. Postmodernism is often associated with schools of thought such as deconstruction and post-structuralism. Postmodernism relies on critical theory, which considers the effects of ideology, society, and history on culture. Postmodernism and critical theory commonly criticize universalist ideas of objective reality, morality, truth, human nature, reason, language, and social progress.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmodernism#:~:text=11%20External%20links-,Definition,of%20economic%20and%20political%20power.

Modernism is a somewhat of a synonym for standard, since you could say that what makes society "modern" compared to "non modern" is standards. Like the concept of "public road", services, measurements, procedure, rules and practices. Another thing I noticed too that although "modernism" is considered to be more of a standard, or unmoving point, "postmodernism" which is a derivative of it, is actually a movement without a certain place. It's a notion, as many had described, which is again, very much confusing.

I've read a few books on japanese religion. it's a pretty complex subject and they still are a deeply religious people. the common mistake is in presuming non-abrahamic religions are anything comparable to abrahamic ones.

the central beliefs of the japanese are ancestor worship, which is the belief that their deceased ancestors are existing beings with elevated powers that must be honored and treated with respect, and the weight of their ancestors presses on their day to day life. this is still a very common belief, and contributes to things such as the "wow you can drop your wallet in japan and no one steals it!". the reason no one steals it is because if they even think to the very thought would be witnessed by their deceased family and would be a betrayal to them. it's really difficult to explain the whole thing without writing a chapter on it, but this ancestor worship evolves into regional cults based around common ancestors, and the imperial line is tied into this ancestor worship and is a sort of national ancestor that the entire nation worships. there is no separation between government and this ancestor worship religion in japan, they are the same.

buddhism is a foreign religion that is at odds with ancestor worship. it was modified to be accepted by the japanese. there have been various laws and pogroms against buddhism in the past there. nowadays it is similar to christianity though it has had more time to sink in its influence. today when a japanese person prays, they pray first to their ancestral line, then to buddha, then to the abrahamic god. this seems ridiculous to someone with an abrahamic mindset, and well it is kind of ridiculous but that's what being a linguistically isolated animistic culture is like.

oh the animism is worth mentioning too, they are one of the only sophisticated cultures to retain a significant amount of animistic beliefs. other examples are finland and filipinos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14360101
Eh, there are some clades of I2 and even C that survived all later migrations. But most I2 is from Steppe Chads. The story of I1 is different in that the MRCA likely came into being after initial waves of Indo-Europeanization had been over for some time and then experienced founder effects after, which, I don't know of any similar events in prehistory.

>U was originally WHG
U is not WHG. U predates WHG pretty significantly, like tens of thousands of years. Most clades of U5 specifically, especially around southern France/northern Spain where it initially dispersed is WHG in origin as is almost all modern I Y-DNA. But there are other clades of U5 aren't even ultimately European in origin. U itself likely dispersed among whatever populations diverged from ANE and other west Eurasians and not quite in Europe yet, somewhere further east as far back as the Lower Paleolithic. I think the event you're referring to specifically was the Saami-Berber connection, where the maternal haplogroup diverged just after the LGM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How will modern tech affect future perceptions of history?
posts.com:
Those of us who grew up in the past couple decades were used to viewing history through the lens of really shitty photo and video, eg. watching some grainy black and white film of WW2 with wacky music played over the top. Even as colour photography and video began to become common in the post-war years, it was still of somewhat poor quality in most cases right up until the 90s.

Future generations will not have this problem. They will have unprecedented access to footage depicting everyday life and important events EXACTLY as they were seen through human eyes.

People 100 years from now will be able to watch footage of the Ukraine war, the covid pandemic, the Afghanistan withdrawal etc with video and sound quality identical to as if they had experienced it in person. People 200 years from now will be able to access endless video and audio recordings of major 21st century figures like Donald Trump, Barack Obama, Osama Bin Laden etc. People 300 years from now might be able to watch a video of some random guy in 2022 recording himself taking a shit as if they were right there in the room with him.

What kind of effect is this going to have on humanity's perceptions of history in the future? Will they feel more intimately connected to events that happened in the 21st century, because of being able to see them in such quality and detail? Will it be harder for people to lie about and obfuscate history, because there will be too many accurate contemporary sources to debunk those lies?

You're using a socialist interpretation of jesus. The Christian view about what christ said about the poor and rich was that it's only difficult and not impossible for a rich person to be saved

Not because they are rich but because wealth created more types of temptation, like having money to burn leads a person to alcoholism and sexual sins.

And being rich makes you more likely to fall into pride and worldliness than a poor person. Because you have a higher social status and more stuff.

And not all poor people are moral or humble people. Though it's easier for them to be because they don't have the same temptations that come with wealth.

So rich people aren't inherently bad, they can live humble and live holy lives and go to heaven too without becoming poor. And poor people aren't inherently better than rich people.

Finally the recommendation of Jesus that the rich man he talked to to give up his wealth is only a final resort for rich people who cant escape from the temptations which come with wealth. It's not a requirement for everyone to give everything they have away but only a extreme method for people who can't escape from their pride and sin due to wealth.

So The church can fund cathedrals and have good looking vestments and church architecture because if the church has the means it should give it 100% for God. Old testament priests and temple also had fine vestments and temples decorated with gold and the finest materials this is not "pagan".

That being said you should live poor in spirit as a rich man by not being materialistic and worldly.
